descriptionSet.description: On this sample calender poster of Empire Calender Manufacturing Co., Calcutta we see different working processes in a Bidi-factory. From the manufacturing processes in the upper part of the image we are lead towards the disposal in the centre and the arrangements being made for transporting the final product to the costumer, ready for consumption.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: On this sample calender poster of Empire Calender Manufacturing Co., Calcutta we see different working processes in a Bidi-factory. From the manufacturing processes in the upper part of the image we are lead towards the disposal in the centre and the arrangements being made for transporting the final product to the costumer, ready for consumption. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: We might note that it is the production of those cigarettes, not the smoking of them, that is valorized through recognition: apparently smoking is an issue taken up separately and probably later, and rather divorced from the value of productivity for the nation. All in all, an important aspect of these visions are the way that everyday labor and craftsmanship contribute to the modern nation. (Sandria B. Freitag)(gs)
related literature: Braudel, Fernand 1981. "The Structures of Everyday Life". London: Collins. (gs)
related literature: de Certeau, Michel 1984. "The Practices of Everyday Life" . Berkeley: University of California Press. (gs)

related literature: Storey, John 1999. "Cultural Consumption and Everyday Life". New York: Oxford University Press. (gs)
